sen.j: ないの神（なゐの神）は、日本神話に登場する地震の神 である。
sen.e: Nainokami is a deity of earthquakes described in the Japanese Mythology.
sen.cmt: 原文の「(神道)」はリンクでしたので削除しました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』の推古天皇紀に、推古天皇7年（599年）夏に大和地方を中心とする大地震があり、その後、諸国に「地震神」（なゐのかみ）を祀らせたとある。
sen.e: In records of the reign of Empress Suiko in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), it is described that, in summer of the seventh year of her reign (599 C.E.), a temblor struck the capital regions, and an order was issued to offer worship to "the deity of earthquakes" (Nainokami).

According to the records of the reign of Empress Suiko in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), in the summer of the seventh year of her reign (599 C.E.), a large earthquake struck the center of Yamato and an order was issued to offer worship to "the deity of earthquakes" (Nainokami).

sen.j: 「なゐ」は地震のことであるので、これは神名ではなく「野の神」「海の神」のような神格を表したものである。
sen.e: "Nai" refers to earthquakes, so it is not a jinmyo (name of deity) but a reference of divinity, like "No no kami" (deity of field) or "Umi no kami" (deity of the sea).

sen.j: 後に鹿島神宮にある要石（かなめいし）が地震をおさえているとの伝承から、鹿島神宮の祭神であるタケミカヅチが地震を防ぐ神とされるようになった。
sen.e: In later periods, the transmission of legends regarding the "kanameishi" (pivot stone) at the Kashima Jingu Shrine led to the belief that the shrine's central deity Takemikazuchi was a protector against earthquakes,

sen.e: In later periods, legends about the "kanameishi", a stone which is supposed to suppress earthquakes, at Kashima Jingu Shrine led to the belief that the shrine's central deity, Takemikazuchi, was a guardian against earthquakes.

sen.j: しかし、記紀にはタケミカヅチと地震を関連づけるような記述はない。
sen.e: The mythologies transmitted by Kojiki and Nihonshoki, however, provide no descriptions of Takemikazuchi with clear attributes as protective deity against earthquakes.

sen.e: However, neither the "Kojiki" nor the "Nihonshoki" mention any connection between Takemikazuchi and earthquakes.

sen.j: 三重県名張市に式内社の名居神社（ないじんじゃ）があり、これが伊賀国における「なゐの神」を祀る神社であったとする説がある。
sen.e: Some have suggested that a shikinaisha (shrine listed in the Engishiki) in Nabari City Mie Prefecture, the Nai Jinja Shrine, was a shrine dedicated to Nainokami in Iga Province.

Some have suggested that Nai Jinja Shrine in Nabari City, Mie Prefecture, which is listed in the Engishiki (a 10th century book of laws and regulations), was originally dedicated to Nainokami of Iga Province (now western Mie Prefecture).
